sub_topic: Find the volume form of a given metric.
message_1: A two-dimensional surface has metric given by $ds^2 = 4(dx)^2 + 9(dy)^2$. Find the volume form of the surface.
message_2:
To find the volume form of the surface, we first need to compute the determinant of the metric tensor. The metric tensor for the given metric is:

$$
g = \begin{pmatrix}
4 & 0 \\
0 & 9
\end{pmatrix}
$$

The determinant of the metric tensor is:

$$
\det(g) = \det \begin{pmatrix}
4 & 0 \\
0 & 9
\end{pmatrix} = 4 \cdot 9 - 0 \cdot 0 = 36
$$

Now, we can compute the square root of the determinant:

$$
\sqrt{\det(g)} = \sqrt{36} = 6
$$

The volume form of the surface is given by the square root of the determinant of the metric tensor times the differential 2-form:

$$
\text{vol} = \sqrt{\det(g)} \, dx \wedge dy = 6 \, dx \wedge dy
$$

So, the volume form of the surface is $6 \, dx \wedge dy$.
